advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil 3: three micro-computers in one!"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1982 HEATHKIT CENTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Best''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"List your technical requirements, Hewlett-Packard is ready to answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> The renaissance machine is a "one-of-a-kind" system for the "one-of-a-kind" person who demands and will not settle for anything less than, the best.</font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, August 1983 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Empire Strikes Back"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE EXTRACT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PASOPIA 16 JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris"><a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (OCTOBER, 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Particuliar sign : painter and musician''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 3 PAGE U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>First HX-20 U.S. advert (september 1982)<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The size, of course, is a dead giveaway. But don't let the size fool you. The HX-20 is not a toy. Or a glorified calculator.<br> It's a computer.<br> A real computer with 16K RAM<br>...<br> Surprised that a computer like the HX-20 should come from Epson?<br> You shouldn't be. Because we have been building computers in Japan since 1978. And we have been practicing ultra-high-quality precision manufacturing for a lot longer than that.<br><br> We didn't jump right into the American microcomputer market. We could afford to bide our time; to wait for the product that was going to stand America on its ears.<br> This is it.<br> The Epson HX-20</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/" target="_blank">Soichiro's Oga</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>First advert of the Model 100.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advertising for the MZ 1500 (with the Quick Disk drive) in a Japanese magazine.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE RECORDER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

computer.description:
Iskra DELTA 800 was derived from the Digital PDP-11/34, compatible to the DELTA family. It could be connected to other computer systems like DEC, IBM, UNIVAC, and others.
It had extended addressing capability (hence, could support 4 MB of RAM), was running somewhat modified RSX 11M, called Delta M OS, and ran J11 Digital Equipment processor (as all PDPs 11 did).
There were several programming languages written for its operating system: ASSEMBLER, COBOL, FORTRAN, BASIC and PASCAL. Iskra Delta was one of the biggest producers of computer systems in former Yugoslavia. Their systems could be found in almost all large companies in Yugoslavia.
More info needed! Thanks to Delimir Purgar and Bostjan Lemut for some info. <\font>
